verses.text: This is the law of the guilt offering: It is most holy.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the guilt offering (asham) is set apart as most holy, as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: In the place where they kill the burnt offering, they shall kill the guilt offering, and its blood shall be thrown against the sides of the altar.
verses.comment: Follows Hebrew order; blood is dashed or thrown, a technical sacrificial term.

verses.text: And all its fat he shall offer from it: the fat tail, and the fat that covers the entrails,
verses.comment: ‘Fat tail’ is explicit, matches common ESV/NASB rendering.

verses.text: both kidneys, and the fat that is on them or on the loins, and the long lobe of liver that he shall remove with the kidneys.
verses.comment: ‘Long lobe of the liver’ renders Hebrew ‘yoteret’.

verses.text: The priest shall burn them on the altar as a food offering to the LORD. It is a guilt offering.
verses.comment: ‘Food offering’ is Hebrew ‘ishsheh’.

verses.text: Every male among the priests may eat of it. It shall be eaten in a holy place; it is most holy.
verses.comment: Preserves restriction to male priests.

verses.text: The guilt offering is like the sin offering; the law is the same for both. The priest who makes atonement with it shall have it.
verses.comment: ‘Law is the same’ renders Hebrew ‘torah achat’.

verses.text: And the priest who offers anyone’s burnt offering shall have for himself the skin of the burnt offering that he has offered.
verses.comment: Priest receives the skin; literal rendering.

verses.text: And every grain offering baked in an oven, or prepared in a pan or on a griddle, belongs to the priest who offers it.
verses.comment: Clarifies different methods of grain offerings preparation.

verses.text: But every other grain offering, mixed with oil or dry, shall belong to all the sons of Aaron, one as much as another.
verses.comment: ‘One as much as another’ is Hebrew ‘ish ke’achiv’—equal share.

verses.text: And this is the law of the sacrifice of peace offerings that one may offer to the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Peace offering’ is Hebrew ‘shelamim’.

verses.text: If he offers it for a thanksgiving, then he shall offer with the sacrifice of thanksgiving unleavened loaves mixed with oil, unleavened wafers spread with oil, and loaves of fine flour well mixed with oil.
verses.comment: Literal types of bread as found in the Hebrew.

verses.text: With the sacrifice of his thanksgiving peace offering he shall bring his offering with loaves of leavened bread.
verses.comment: Note leavened bread is allowed for this type of offering.

verses.text: And from it he shall offer one loaf from each offering as a contribution to the LORD. It shall belong to the priest who throws the blood of the peace offerings.
verses.comment: ‘Contribution’ is Hebrew ‘terumah’.

verses.text: And the flesh of the sacrifice of his thanksgiving peace offering shall be eaten on the day of his offering; he shall not leave any of it until morning.
verses.comment: Literal; ‘until morning’ means all must be consumed that day.

verses.text: But if the sacrifice of his offering is a vow or a freewill offering, it shall be eaten on the day that he offers his sacrifice; and on the next day what remains of it shall be eaten.
verses.comment: ‘Vow’ and ‘freewill offering’ are technical terms.

verses.text: But what remains of the flesh of the sacrifice on the third day shall be burned with fire.
verses.comment: Verse clarifies all leftovers on the third day are to be burned.

verses.text: If any of the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offering is eaten on the third day, it will not be accepted, nor will it be credited to him. It shall be considered an abomination, and the person who eats of it shall bear his iniquity.
verses.comment: 'Abomination' is literal Hebrew 'pigul'.

verses.text: And flesh that touches any unclean thing shall not be eaten. It shall be burned with fire. All who are clean may eat of the flesh,
verses.comment: Distribution between cleanliness and uncleanness.

verses.text: but the person who eats the flesh of the sacrifice of the LORD’s peace offerings while he is unclean, that person shall be cut off from his people.
verses.comment: ‘Cut off’ is literal Hebrew, possibly means excommunication or death.

verses.text: And if anyone touches any unclean thing, whether human uncleanness or an unclean animal or any unclean detestable creature, and then eats some of the flesh of the sacrifice of the LORD’s peace offerings, that person shall be cut off from his people.
verses.comment: ‘Detestable creature’ is literal for Hebrew ‘sheqets’.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Very literal; direct speech.

verses.text: Speak to the people of Israel, saying, You shall eat no fat, of ox or sheep or goat.
verses.comment: Prohibition is strict; Hebrew covers all sacrificial animals.

verses.text: The fat of an animal that dies of itself and the fat of one that is torn by beasts may be used for any other purpose, but you must not eat it.
verses.comment: Fat may be used for other uses, not food.

verses.text: For every person who eats any fat of animals from which food offering may be made to the LORD, that person shall be cut off from his people.
verses.comment: Echoes other prohibitions on eating specific fats.

verses.text: Moreover, you shall eat no blood whatever, whether of bird or of animal, in any of your dwellings.
verses.comment: Absolute prohibition on blood; ‘whatever’ is Hebrew intensifier.

verses.text: Whoever eats any blood, that person shall be cut off from his people.
verses.comment: Harshest penalty for eating blood.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Formulaic introduction.

verses.text: Speak to the people of Israel, saying, Whoever offers the sacrifice of his peace offerings to the LORD shall bring his offering to the LORD from the sacrifice of his peace offerings.
verses.comment: Literally rendered, slight redundancy is in Hebrew.

verses.text: His own hands shall bring the LORD’s food offerings. He shall bring the fat with the breast, that the breast may be waved as a wave offering before the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Wave offering’ is technical sacrificial term.

verses.text: The priest shall burn the fat on the altar, but the breast shall be for Aaron and his sons.
verses.comment: Emphasizes division of parts between altar and priests.

verses.text: And the right thigh you shall give to the priest as a contribution from the sacrifices of your peace offerings.
verses.comment: ‘Contribution’ again is ‘terumah’ in Hebrew.

verses.text: The one among the sons of Aaron who offers the blood of the peace offerings and the fat shall have the right thigh as his portion.
verses.comment: ‘His portion’ is Hebrew ‘himna’—literal.

verses.text: For the breast that is waved and the thigh that is contributed I have taken from the people of Israel, out of the sacrifices of their peace offerings, and have given them to Aaron the priest and to his sons, as a perpetual due from the people of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Perpetual due’ is Hebrew ‘statute forever’.

verses.text: This is the portion for Aaron and his sons from the LORD’s food offerings, from the day they were presented to serve as priests of the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Presented’ as Hebrew ‘to draw near’ (presented for service).

verses.text: The LORD commanded this to be given them by the people of Israel, from the day that he anointed them. It is a perpetual statute throughout their generations.
verses.comment: ‘Perpetual statute’ translates Hebrew ‘chuqat olam’.

verses.text: This is the law of the burnt offering, of the grain offering, of the sin offering, of the guilt offering, of the ordination offering, and of the sacrifice of peace offerings,
verses.comment: ‘Ordination offering’ is Hebrew ‘milu’im’—offering for consecrating priests.

verses.text: which the LORD commanded Moses on Mount Sinai, on the day he commanded the people of Israel to bring their offerings to the LORD, in the wilderness of Sinai.
verses.comment: Follows Hebrew order of events.
